verdict.summary: TLS handshake failed because the server's SSL certificate has expired. Node.js strict TLS validation rejects expired certificates by default.

dead_ends.why_fails: Disables all certificate validation, exposing the application to man-in-the-middle attacks

dead_ends.action: Pinning the expired certificate in the trust store
dead_ends.why_fails: The certificate is expired; pinning it does not make it valid and other clients will still reject it

workarounds.action: Renew the SSL certificate on the target server
workarounds.how: Use certbot or your CA's renewal process: certbot renew --force-renewal, then restart the server

workarounds.action: Update the system CA certificate bundle
workarounds.how: Run 'sudo update-ca-certificates' on Debian/Ubuntu or 'sudo update-ca-trust' on RHEL/CentOS
workarounds.condition: when the issue is an outdated root CA bundle on the client

leads_to.condition: when misconfiguring TLS version after encountering certificate errors

preceded_by.condition: when TLS handshake failures cause connection resets

frequently_confused_with.distinction: CERT_HAS_EXPIRED means the certificate itself is expired, while ERR_SSL_WRONG_VERSION_NUMBER means there is a TLS protocol version mismatch
